abstract.p: New study finds that professional ballet dancers are injured just as often, and just as seriously, as athletes who play rough sports (S)

block.p: Ballet is not usually considered a contact sport -- at least not when all goes well on stage -- but that doesn't necessarily make it safer than football.
A new study has found that professional ballet dancers are injured just as often, and just as seriously, as athletes who play rough sports.
Ballet is not usually considered a contact sport -- at least not when all goes well on stage -- but that doesn't necessarily make it safer than football.
A new study has found that professional ballet dancers are injured just as often, and just as seriously, as athletes who play rough sports.

Dr. Ronald Smith of the University of Washington, writing in the journal Anxiety, Stress and Coping, based the conclusion on a study of 46 dancers with the Pacific Northwest Ballet Company in Seattle.
The researchers found that the dancers had an injury rate of 61 percent in the eight months studied, a rate the study said was comparable to that for football players and wrestlers.
The study looked at 31 men and 15 women, on average just over 26 years old.
Defining injury as a medical problem that restricted participation for at least a day, the researchers found that the average time lost from injury was 10.5 days for the dancers.
The goal of the study was to try to understand the psychology of injury among athletes and performers.
